when_to_say: When greeting or wishing for peace
example: Salaam is often used to greet someone politely.

when_to_say: When referring to a book
example: I borrowed a kitaab from the library.

when_to_say: When talking about educational institutions
example: My children study in a madrasa near our home.

when_to_say: When talking about meals or eating
example: The ta'aam served here is very delicious.

when_to_say: When discussing joy or contentment
example: Helping others brings true sa'aada to the heart.

when_to_say: When describing someone or something attractive
example: This painting is very jameel.

when_to_say: When referring to power or capability
example: The athlete's quwa amazed everyone at the competition.

when_to_say: When expressing affection or deep liking
example: Love is called al-hubb in Arabic.

when_to_say: When referring to a home or dwelling
example: Their bayt is located on a quiet street.

when_to_say: When describing an urban area
example: I live in a large madina.

when_to_say: When referring to the atmosphere or heavens
example: The samaa was clear and blue this morning.

when_to_say: When expressing thanks or appreciation
example: He showed shukr for all the help he received.

when_to_say: When describing illumination or brightness
example: The room was filled with noor from the window.

when_to_say: When talking about emotions or the heart organ
example: Her qalb was filled with joy upon hearing the news.

when_to_say: When discussing tasks or jobs
example: He completed his amal before the deadline.

when_to_say: When referring to moments or durations
example: Punctuality is about valuing your waqt.

when_to_say: When talking about companions or allies
example: A true sadeeq stands by you in all circumstances.

when_to_say: When discussing trips or travels
example: Their safar to the mountains was refreshing.

when_to_say: When referring to relatives or close ones
example: His usra supports him in all his endeavors.

when_to_say: When discussing optimism or aspirations
example: Never lose amal even in tough situations.

when_to_say: When discussing independence or liberty
example: Hurriya is a basic right for everyone.

when_to_say: When referring to paths or streets
example: Follow the tareeq until you reach the destination.

when_to_say: When referring to someone who teaches
example: The mu'allim guided his students with care.

when_to_say: When talking about understanding or expertise
example: Seek ilm throughout your life.

when_to_say: When discussing existence or living
example: Every moment of hayaat is precious.

when_to_say: When talking about large bodies of water
example: The bahr was calm and serene.

when_to_say: When discussing endurance or tolerance
example: Sabr is a virtue in challenging times.

when_to_say: When describing something that is stunningly beautiful
example: The view from the top of the mountain is jameel lil-ghaaya.

when_to_say: When greeting someone and asking about their well-being
example: When meeting a friend, you can say: Kayfa haluka?

when_to_say: When reassuring or consoling someone
example: If someone apologizes, you can respond with: La ba's.

when_to_say: When expressing gratitude or satisfaction
example: After overcoming a challenge, you can say: Alhamdu lillah.

when_to_say: When requesting assistance
example: In a tough situation, you might say: Ahtaj ila musaadah.

when_to_say: When referring to the early morning hours
example: Muslims often pray at waqt al-fajr.

when_to_say: When encouraging optimism and determination
example: With hard work, kul shay' mumkin.

when_to_say: When expressing a desire for knowledge
example: If you're in a classroom, you might say: Ureed an ata'allam.

when_to_say: When talking about a close and trusted companion
example: She confided in her sadeeq muqarrab.

when_to_say: When describing a large residence
example: They moved to a bayt kabeer in the suburbs.

when_to_say: When discussing habits for better health
example: Maintaining an usloob hayaat sahee is essential for wellbeing.

when_to_say: When describing a cheerful expression
example: Her ibtisaama mushriqa brightened everyone's day.

when_to_say: When discussing a tough challenge or fight
example: They faced a ma'rakah sa'bah but emerged victorious.

when_to_say: When describing deep affection or compassion
example: She had a qalb malee' bil-hubb for everyone around her.

when_to_say: When referring to someone with high aspirations
example: He is known as a shakhs dhu tumuh who always aims high.

when_to_say: When describing an informative book
example: He read a kitaab malee' bil-ma'loomat on world history.

when_to_say: When describing a forest or nature
example: The ashjaar aaliya surrounded the house.

when_to_say: When talking about a refreshing drink
example: He drank maa' baarid after a long walk.

when_to_say: When discussing challenges in problem-solving
example: The teacher asked a su'al sa'b to test our knowledge.

when_to_say: When describing a cozy or compact home
example: They lived in a bayt sagheer near the park.

when_to_say: When talking about a fun journey or vacation
example: We had a rihlah mumti'ah to the countryside.

when_to_say: When describing a serene outdoor setting at night
example: They camped taht al-nujoom by the lake.

when_to_say: When complimenting someone’s singing or speaking voice
example: The singer has a sawt jameel that captivates audiences.

when_to_say: When receiving or sharing positive news
example: I heard a khabarun saarun about her promotion at work.

when_to_say: When talking about a large quantity or collection of something
example: The library has a majmu'atun kabeeratun of rare books.

when_to_say: When describing clear and sunny weather
example: We enjoyed a jawwun mushmissun while walking on the beach.

when_to_say: When referring to a differing perspective or view
example: She expressed a ra'yun mukhtalifun on the topic during the discussion.

when_to_say: When referring to a study session with others
example: We have a mudarasatun majmu'iyyatun planned for the weekend.

when_to_say: When acquiring fresh or new information
example: This book provided me with a ma'rifatun jadeedatun that I didn't know before.

when_to_say: When reflecting on a successful endeavor or activity
example: Her project was a tajribatun naajihatun that received much praise.

when_to_say: When talking about leisure or downtime
example: During my waqtun faraaghun, I enjoy reading books and listening to music.

when_to_say: When discussing someone's personal traits or attributes
example: Her taabi'un fardiyyun is what makes her stand out from others.

when_to_say: When discussing a scientific or academic study
example: The fahsun 'ilmiyyun confirmed the hypothesis of the research.

when_to_say: When confirming something with full certainty or proof
example: The tahaqququn taammun of the data is crucial for the accuracy of the report.

when_to_say: When discussing something in a formal or work-related context
example: We had a muhadhathatun mihniyyatun to discuss the project's progress.

when_to_say: When referring to a designated area for sports activities
example: The mintaqatun riyaadiyyatun in the park is always busy with athletes.

when_to_say: When referring to the success of a business venture
example: His najahun tijariyyun in the tech industry has been remarkable.

when_to_say: When referring to a person who is well-recognized in society
example: He is a rajulun ma'roofun in his community for his charitable work.

when_to_say: When talking about young people full of energy
example: The team of shabaabun nasheetun worked tirelessly to complete the project.

when_to_say: When describing a strong, intense defense, either in sports or metaphorically
example: The team showed a mudaafaatun sharisatun in the final minutes of the game.

when_to_say: When acknowledging a harsh or challenging situation
example: Facing the waaqi'un sa'abun of the economy, many businesses have struggled.

when_to_say: When referring to experiences that provide valuable lessons or advantages
example: He shared his tajaarebun mufeedatun from traveling the world with us.

when_to_say: When discussing a challenging or tough encounter
example: The leader had to face a muwajahatun sa'abatun with the opposition during negotiations.

when_to_say: When referring to a profound or thorough understanding of a subject
example: He has a fahmun 'ameequn of philosophy that makes him a respected teacher.

when_to_say: When discussing someone's mental or intellectual capacity
example: Her qudratun fikriyyatun allows her to solve complex problems with ease.

when_to_say: When emphasizing teamwork or collaboration that brings results
example: The ta'awunun fa'alaalun between the departments led to a successful project.

when_to_say: When referring to a powerful or influential connection or relationship
example: He has a mu'aarafatun qawiyyatun with many influential people in the industry.

when_to_say: When referring to work done with care and precision
example: His amalun mutqanun was evident in every project he completed.

when_to_say: When talking about someone's ability to think critically or solve problems
example: Her muhaaratun tafkeeriyyatun is a valuable asset in the workplace.

when_to_say: When referring to one's ability to endure or tolerate mental challenges or stress
example: His tahammulun fikriyyun helped him stay focused during difficult exams.

when_to_say: When referring to someone with genuine honesty and moral integrity
example: He is known for his amaanatun saadiqatun in both personal and professional matters.

when_to_say: When referring to someone’s sensitivity or talent in arts
example: Her hissun fanniyyun is evident in her stunning paintings and sculptures.

when_to_say: When discussing a delicate or controversial topic
example: The mas'alatun hareejatun regarding privacy was raised during the meeting.

when_to_say: When emphasizing a thorough comprehension of something
example: Their tafahhumun 'ameequn of the issue led to a peaceful resolution.

when_to_say: When discussing the ability to withstand hardship or difficulties
example: She showed a remarkable qudratun 'ala at-tahammul during the challenging times.

when_to_say: When referring to someone's understanding of social situations
example: His hissun ijtima'iyyun allows him to navigate group dynamics effectively.

when_to_say: When talking about surpassing or overcoming obstacles
example: Their tajawuzun lit-tahaddiyyat was evident when they succeeded in the project despite difficulties.

when_to_say: When referring to differing views or disagreements
example: There was a tafawutun fi ar-ra'y during the debate on the new policy.

when_to_say: When referring to innovative or imaginative thinking
example: His fikrun ibda'iyyun helped the company come up with groundbreaking ideas.

when_to_say: When describing a challenging or harsh situation
example: They had to face the waaqi'un sa'bun of the market crash with determination.

when_to_say: When celebrating an outstanding achievement
example: Their najahun mubhirun in the competition made them the talk of the town.

when_to_say: When referring to a gap in understanding or knowledge
example: There is a fajwatun fikriyyatun between the two theories that needs to be addressed.

when_to_say: When highlighting someone’s firm resolve
example: His israarun qawiyyun to achieve his goals was evident in every step he took.

when_to_say: When referring to a fresh burst of creative ideas or efforts
example: The team's ibda'un mutajaddidun in the new campaign brought in great results.

when_to_say: When describing someone who is actively involved or contributing
example: She is a fa'ilun ijaabiyyun in every project she joins.

when_to_say: When describing a person with strong determination and willpower
example: His irada'tun fooladhiyyatun helped him overcome the toughest challenges.

when_to_say: When referring to exceptional bravery or courage
example: Her shaja'ah faa'iqah was recognized when she risked her life to save others.

when_to_say: When talking about the ability to endure difficult situations with a sense of responsibility
example: He showed tahammulun mas'oolun when handling the crisis at work.

when_to_say: When describing a person with an unwavering decision
example: Her azmun qawiyyun helped her succeed in the face of adversity.

when_to_say: When referring to a person who is focused and committed to a cause
example: He approaches every task with ittijahun jaaddun.

when_to_say: When describing someone’s ability to communicate effectively
example: Her maharatun fi at-tawasul helped her build strong professional relationships.

when_to_say: When referring to an optimism that can be visibly felt or seen
example: His tafaa'ulun malmoosun lifted the spirits of the entire team.

when_to_say: When talking about a desire to be brave or courageous in facing something
example: His raghbatun shaja'ah led him to take on risky ventures without hesitation.

when_to_say: When referring to an idea that stimulates creativity or motivation
example: The fikratun mulhima sparked a new project in the team.

when_to_say: When describing an overwhelming or extraordinary happiness
example: She had marahun baahirun when she received the good news.

when_to_say: When referring to a particularly hard or demanding situation
example: He faced a tahaddin sa'bun but handled it with determination.

when_to_say: When describing a spirit of collaboration that produces good results
example: The team's ta'awunun ijaabiyyun led to a successful completion of the project.

when_to_say: When referring to someone with a strong and unyielding will
example: His irada'tun saareematun helped him achieve his dreams despite many obstacles.

when_to_say: When describing a management style or supervision that leads to success
example: The project succeeded due to the ishraafun naajihun of the team leader.

when_to_say: When talking about focused and committed study or learning
example: He approached his exams with mudaarasatun jaaddatun to ensure good results.

when_to_say: When referring to a small amount of help or support
example: The team needed musa'adatun qaleelatun to get started.

when_to_say: When referring to a profound or extensive understanding of a subject
example: Her ma'rifatan 'ameeqatan in literature was impressive to all.

when_to_say: When describing a person who has accumulated valuable life experiences
example: Her tajaareebun ghaniyyatun in various countries made her an expert in cultural studies.

when_to_say: When describing a success that is extraordinary or surprising
example: Her najahun mubhirun in the competition amazed everyone.

when_to_say: When referring to a clear and focused understanding of something
example: He has a ru'yatun waadihah for the future of the company.

when_to_say: When referring to a situation where there is a need to finish something in a short period
example: The project turned into a musaara'atun fil waqt, but they managed to finish on time.

when_to_say: When referring to an act of kindness or something done beautifully
example: She performed a ma'roofun jameelun by helping the needy.

when_to_say: When referring to a specific skill or expertise in a technical field
example: His mahaaratun fanniyyatun in programming is exceptional.

meaning_bangla: যে ব্যক্তি তার নীতিগুলি রক্ষা করে
when_to_say: When describing someone who remains true to their values or beliefs
example: He is a haafidhun 'ala mabadi'ihi, never compromising on his principles.

when_to_say: When referring to substantial progress in any field
example: The company made taqaddumun mulhiqun last year in terms of innovation.

when_to_say: When referring to someone accepting accountability or responsibility
example: She demonstrated tahammulun mas'ooliyyatin by managing the project alone.

when_to_say: When referring to someone's ability to make people laugh or feel joy
example: Her hissun fakaahiyyun makes her the life of the party.

when_to_say: When referring to someone who is consistently working hard towards a goal
example: His mulaazamatun da'ubatun led him to complete the task ahead of schedule.

when_to_say: When greeting someone or when you meet someone
example: Marhaban! Kaifa halak? (Hello! How are you?)

when_to_say: When asking for the location of the airport
example: Ayna al-mataar? (Where is the airport?)

when_to_say: When asking about the price of something
example: Kami al-sa'ru? (How much is the price?)

when_to_say: When responding to someone who thanked you
example:
Person: Shukran! (Thank you!) 
Response: Laa shukra 'ala waajib. (You're welcome)

when_to_say: When describing something or someone who is late
example: Ana muta'akhkhirun. (I am late.)

when_to_say: When offering someone to do something or to go ahead
example: Tafaddal, jalis! (Please, sit down!)

when_to_say: When expressing that you are hungry
example: Ana jaa'i'un. (I am hungry.)

when_to_say: When asking a reason or explanation
example: Limaazaa anta muta'akhkhirun? (Why are you late?)

when_to_say: When affirming something or agreeing to something
example:
Person: Hal turid al-ma'isha fi madinah? (Do you want to live in the city?) 
Response: Bil-tabe'i! (Of course!)

meaning_english: I am on my way to the library
when_to_say: When informing someone where you are going
example: Ana fi tareeqi ila al-maktabah. (I am on my way to the library.)

when_to_say: When asking someone where they are
example: Ayna anta? (Where are you?)

when_to_say: When referring to a beautiful woman
example: Hiya imra'atun jameelah. (She is a beautiful woman.)

when_to_say: When talking about the possibility of exercising
example: Iza kaanati ar-riyaadhatu mumkinatan, sanatadreebu. (If exercise is possible, we will train.)

when_to_say: When giving a positive comment about something
example: Innahu jayyidun jiddan. (It is very good.)

when_to_say: When asking someone what they are doing
example: Maza taf'alu? (What are you doing?)

when_to_say: When expressing that you like or love coffee
example: Ana uhibbu al-qahwata. (I love coffee.)

when_to_say: When admitting you don’t know something
example: Ana fi al-waaqi'i laa 'arifu. (In fact, I don’t know.)

when_to_say: When expressing happiness or joy
example: Ana sa'idun jiddan. (I am very happy.)

when_to_say: When describing a lecture as good
example: Al-muhaadarah jayyidah. (The lecture is good.)

when_to_say: When asking someone if they understand
example: Hal tafhamu? (Do you understand?)

meaning_english: I am on my way to the library
when_to_say: When talking about going somewhere
example: Ana fi tareeqi ila al-maktabah. (I am on my way to the library.)

when_to_say: When inquiring about the time of an event
example: Mataa satakoonu al-haflatu? (When will the party be?)

when_to_say: When something seems unusual or strange
example: Haadha ghareebiyyun jiddan. (This is very strange.)

meaning_bangla: তুমি কি ভ্রমণ করতে পছন্দ করো?
when_to_say: When asking if someone enjoys traveling
example: Hal tuhibbu as-safara? (Do you like traveling?)

meaning_english: I don’t understand what you’re saying
meaning_bangla: আমি যা বলছি তা বুঝি না
when_to_say: When you do not understand what someone is saying
example: Laa afhamu ma taqoolu. (I don’t understand what you’re saying.)

when_to_say: When you need help from someone
example: Ahtaaju ila ma'oonatik. (I need your help.)

meaning_english: Where can I find the restaurant?
when_to_say: When you are looking for a restaurant
example: Ayna ajidu al-mat'ama? (Where can I find the restaurant?)

meaning_english: I am at home right now
when_to_say: When you want to tell someone you are at home
example: Ana fi manzili al-aan. (I am at home right now.)

when_to_say: When expressing love for swimming
example: Uhibbu as-sawiyyata. (I love swimming.)

when_to_say: When asking about someone's rank or position
example: Man huwa 'alaa fi ar-ratabah? (Who is higher in rank?)

meaning_english: You are in a difficult situation
when_to_say: When describing someone's challenging situation
example: Anta fi wadh'in sa'b. (You are in a difficult situation.)

word: هَلْ تَحْتَاجُ إِلَى مَزِيدٍ مِنَ الْمَعْلُومَاتِ؟
pronunciation: hal tahtaju ila mazeed min al-ma'loomaat?
when_to_say: When offering to provide more details or information
example: Hal tahtaju ila mazeed min al-ma'loomaat? (Do you need more information?)

when_to_say: When you are actively listening to someone
example: Ana astami'u ilayki. (I am listening to you.)

word: مَا هُوَ الرَّأْيُ فِي هَذَا الْمَوْضُوعِ؟
pronunciation: ma huwa ar-ra'yu fi hadha al-mawdhu'i?
meaning_english: What is the opinion on this topic?
when_to_say: When you want to ask someone's opinion on a subject
example: Ma huwa ar-ra'yu fi hadha al-mawdhu'i? (What is the opinion on this topic?)

when_to_say: When advising someone to be honest and transparent
example: Laa taktumul haqaaiqa. (Do not hide the facts.)

when_to_say: When asking about someone's holiday or time off
example: Mataa satakoonu ijaazatuka? (When will your vacation be?)

when_to_say: When talking about your hobby of reading
example: Uhibbu qira'ata al-kutubi. (I love reading books.)

meaning_english: Do you know how to swim?
when_to_say: When asking if someone knows how to swim
example: Hal tajeedu as-sabaahata? (Do you know how to swim?)

meaning_english: We are in a big room
when_to_say: When describing where you are
example: Nahnu fi qaa'atin kabeerat. (We are in a big room.)

meaning_english: What is the response to this?
when_to_say: When asking for a reply to something
example: Ma huwa ar-raddu 'ala hadha? (What is the response to this?)

word: لَا تَخَافْ، كُلُّ شَيْءٍ سَيَكُونُ عَلَى مَا يُرَامُ
pronunciation: laa takhaaf, kullu shay'in sayakoona 'ala ma yuraam
meaning_english: Don't worry, everything will be fine
meaning_bangla: চিন্তা করোনা, সব কিছু ঠিক হয়ে যাবে
when_to_say: When comforting someone who is anxious or worried
example: Laa takhaaf, kullu shay'in sayakoona 'ala ma yuraam. (Don't worry, everything will be fine.)

when_to_say: When you need assistance with something
example: Ahtajuu ila ba'di al-musa'adati. (I need some help.)

meaning_english: What is your opinion on that?
when_to_say: When asking someone's opinion on a particular subject
example: Ma ra'yuka fi dhalika? (What is your opinion on that?)

meaning_english: I am on my way to the library
when_to_say: When you are informing someone about your current location
example: Ana fi tareeqi ila al-maktabati. (I am on my way to the library.)

when_to_say: When talking about people who are present in a particular place
example: Yujadu ba'du an-naasi huna. (There are some people here.)

meaning_english: I will be here for another day
when_to_say: When you want to tell someone that you'll be staying somewhere for a bit longer
example: Sa'akoonu huna li-yawmin aakhar. (I will be here for another day.)

meaning_english: I need a pen for writing
meaning_bangla: লিখার জন্য আমাকে একটি কলম প্রয়োজন
when_to_say: When you are requesting a pen or writing tool
example: Ahtajuu ila fareesin likitaabatihi. (I need a pen for writing.)

meaning_english: What do you do in your free time?
meaning_bangla: তুমি কি করো তোমার অবসর সময়ে?
when_to_say: When asking someone about their hobbies or free time activities
example: Maadha taf'alu fi al-waqtifaaraaghiki? (What do you do in your free time?)

meaning_english: Are you ready for the trip?
when_to_say: When inquiring if someone is ready to travel or go on a trip
example: Hal anta jaahizun lis-safari? (Are you ready for the trip?)

word: نَحْنُ فِي حَاجَةٍ إِلَى مَزِيدٍ مِنَ الْمُوَارِدِ
pronunciation: nahnu fi haajatin ila mazeed min al-mawareedi
meaning_english: We are in need of more resources
when_to_say: When expressing a need for additional resources
example: Nahnu fi haajatin ila mazeed min al-mawareedi. (We are in need of more resources.)

when_to_say: When expressing your love for reading
example: Ana uhibbu qira'ata al-kutub. (I love reading books.)

meaning_english: When will you arrive at the airport?
when_to_say: When asking about the time of someone's arrival at the airport
example: Mataa satasilu ila al-mataari? (When will you arrive at the airport?)

pronunciation: ana mareedun wa ahtaju ila raahat
meaning_english: I am sick and need rest
when_to_say: When you are feeling unwell and need to rest
example: Ana mareedun wa ahtaju ila raahat. (I am sick and need rest.)

meaning_english: He works in a large company
meaning_bangla: সে একটি বড় কোম্পানিতে কাজ করে
when_to_say: When talking about someone's job or place of work
example: Innahu ya'malu fi sharekatin kabeeratin. (He works in a large company.)

word: أَنَا ذَاهِبٌ إِلَى السُّوقِ لِشِرَاءِ غَرَاضٍ
pronunciation: ana dhaahibun ila as-suuqi lishiraa'i gharaadin
meaning_english: I am going to the market to buy groceries
when_to_say: When you are going to the market to buy groceries or essentials
example: Ana dhaahibun ila as-suuqi lishiraa'i gharaadin. (I am going to the market to buy groceries.)

when_to_say: When asking someone if they like to travel
example: Hal tuhibbu as-safara? (Do you like traveling?)

when_to_say: When advising someone to be honest
example: Yajibu 'alayka an takoon saadiqan. (You must be honest.)

meaning_english: Are you sure of your decision?
meaning_bangla: তুমি কি তোমার সিদ্ধান্ত সম্পর্কে নিশ্চিত?
when_to_say: When asking someone if they are confident about their decision
example: Hal anta muta'akkidun min qaraarika? (Are you sure of your decision?)

when_to_say: When asking for directions to the airport
example: Ayna taqa'u al-mataaru? (Where is the airport located?)

when_to_say: When reflecting on how time seems to go by fast
example: Al-waqtu yamurru saree'an. (Time passes quickly.)

meaning_english: I am on my way to the library
when_to_say: When you are going to the library
example: Ana fi tareeqi ila al-maktabati. (I am on my way to the library.)

pronunciation: ahlan wa sahlan fīka fi bayti
when_to_say: When greeting someone who visits your home
example: Ahlan wa sahlan fīka fi bayti. (Welcome to my house.)

meaning_english: Do you know the way to the station?
when_to_say: When asking for directions to the station
example: Hal ta'rifu tareeq al-mahatta? (Do you know the way to the station?)

when_to_say: When asking someone if they have sisters
example: Hal laki akhawaatun? (Do you have sisters?)

when_to_say: When advising someone to make the most of life
example: Al-hayaatu qaseeratun, fastamti' bihā. (Life is short, enjoy it.)

meaning_english: I am proud of his achievements
when_to_say: When expressing pride in someone's achievements
example: Ana fakhurun bimaareebatihi. (I am proud of his achievements.)

meaning_english: You are good at lunch, right?
meaning_bangla: তুমি কি দুপুরের খাবারে ভালো আছো?
when_to_say: When confirming if someone enjoys lunch
example: Anta tafajjoo bial-ghadā'i, saheehun? (You are good at lunch, right?)

word: أَحْبَبْتُ أَنْ أَسْأَلَكُ عَنْ دُرُوسِ الْعَرَبِيَّةِ
meaning_english: I wanted to ask you about Arabic lessons
meaning_bangla: আমি তোমাকে আরবি পাঠ সম্পর্কে জিজ্ঞাসা করতে চেয়েছিলাম
when_to_say: When asking about Arabic lessons
example: Ahbabtu an as'alaaka 'an duroosi al-`arabiyyah. (I wanted to ask you about Arabic lessons.)

when_to_say: When asking for the arrival time of a train
example: Mataa ya'ti al-qitaaru? (When will the train arrive?)

when_to_say: When asking someone if they like tea
example: Hal tuhibbu sharaaba ash-shaayi? (Do you like tea?)

when_to_say: When asking someone if they understand Arabic
example: Hal tafhamu al-`arabiyyah? (Do you understand Arabic?)

when_to_say: When expressing your love for traveling
example: Ana uhibbu as-safara jiddan. (I love traveling very much.)

when_to_say: When you don’t understand something
example: Ana laa afhamu haadhā. (I don’t understand this.)

when_to_say: When asking about the next time you will meet someone
example: Mataa sa'araaka? (When will I see you?)

when_to_say: When expressing your love for reading books
example: Ana uhibbu qara'ata al-kutub. (I love reading books.)

meaning_english: Where can I read these lectures?
meaning_bangla: আমি এই লেকচারগুলি কোথায় পড়তে পারি?
when_to_say: When asking where to read specific lectures
example: Ayna aqra'u haadhihi al-mahaadhira? (Where can I read these lectures?)

word: أَنَا أَذْهَبُ إِلَى الْمَدْرَسَةِ كُلَّ يَوْمٍ
pronunciation: ana adhhabu ila al-madrasaati kulla yawmin
meaning_english: I go to school every day
when_to_say: When talking about your daily routine
example: Ana adhhabu ila al-madrasaati kulla yawmin. (I go to school every day.)

meaning_english: What is your opinion on this?
when_to_say: When asking someone's opinion about something
example: Maa huwa ra'yuka fee haadhaa? (What is your opinion on this?)

meaning_bangla: তুমি কি মিষ্টি মরিচ পছন্দ করো?
when_to_say: When asking if someone likes peppers
example: Hal tuhibbu al-fullful? (Do you like peppers?)

meaning_english: I will go to the market tomorrow
when_to_say: When talking about plans for the next day
example: Ana sa'adhhabu ila as-suuqi ghadan. (I will go to the market tomorrow.)
